text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Sam.
speaker: Sam

text: And I'm Neil.
Have you heard this, Doke Neil?
Question. What's a rat's favourite game?
speaker: Sam

text: I don't know, Sam. What is a rat's favourite game?
Hide and squeak!
speaker: Sam

text: Very funny.
speaker: Neil

text: Well, I’m glad you’re laughing because, as we’ll be finding out in this programme,
speaker: Sam

text: laughter is good for you. In fact, laughter is often called the best medicine.
And it seems that's really true, medically speaking.
Laughing releases anti-stress endorphins into the body,
and there's evidence that people who laugh recover more quickly from illness,
including Covid.
Laughing is an essential part of what makes us human.
speaker: Sam

text: Babies cry straight from birth, but the next sound they make,
often as young as two or three months, is laughter.
And who can hear a baby laugh without laughing themselves?
Laughter is catching.
But before we start tickling off any bones, I have a quiz question for you, Neil,
and it's no laughing matter.
speaker: Sam

text: Laughter can be a serious business.
In fact, there's a scientific field of study into laughter and its effects on the human body.
But what is this study called?
Is it A, GIGLOGY, B, GELOTOLOGY or C, GIFOLOGY?
Did you make those words up, Sam?
speaker: Sam

text: They sound a bit funny to me.
I'll say the study of laughter is called B, GELOTOLOGY.
Okay, Neil, but you'll be laughing on the other side of your face if you're wrong.
Anyway, we'll find out the correct answer later in the programme.
speaker: Sam

text: Someone who's an expert in the study of laughing, whatever it's called,
is Cognitive Neuroscientists, Professor Sophie Scott.
Here she explains to David Edmunds,
presenter of BBC World Service programme The Big Idea,
exactly how a laugh is produced.
Laughing is a variation of breathing.
speaker: rib cage

text: Like breathing, it involves the ribcage.
When you laugh, you get these very, very large,
very fast contractions of the ribcage.
And it's a very primitive way of making a sound.
So you're really just squeezing air out in big bouts.
Each of those individual squeezes gives you both a huff sound.
The ha ha sound you make when you laugh comes from your ribcage.
A structure made of bones, called ribs,
speaker: rib cage

text: in your chest which protects the heart and lungs.
The ribcage works like a drum to amplify a laugh.
It's the reason why jokes are sometimes called rib ticklers.
Professor Scott calls this a very primitive way of making sounds
speaker: primitive

text: because it's simple, natural and essentially human.
The word primitive can be used to describe anything relating to the basic way
humans lived at their early stages of development.
Before money, machines or writing were invented.
Primitive human noises like crying and laughing
linked to a universal human experience.
And this can be seen in the large number of words we use to talk about them.
In English, chuckle, giggle, turtle, cackle and giggle,
all describe different types of laughter.
Right, so how would you describe a giggle, Sam?
Hmm.
I'd say a giggle is laughing in a quiet but uncontrolled way,
like a child who finds something very funny or feels embarrassed.
Unlike a giggle, which is when you blast out a very loud laugh,
often it's something stupid or rude someone has said.
But humans aren't the only animals to laugh.
speaker: guffaw

text: We belong to the same family as other primates like chimpanzees,
gorillas and orangutans, all of whom laugh.
Even rat tickle each other and make squeaky noises like laughter when they play.
Here’s Professor Scott again to take up the story for BBC World Service program
speaker: Neil

text: The Big Idea.
Play's a very important behaviour for mammals,
all mammals play when they're juveniles and some mammals play their whole lives.
And laughter's a sort of an invitation to play to sign that you're playing.
Professor Scott says laughter is an important social tool for all mammals.
Animals, including humans, dogs and whales, which give birth to live young,
speaker: mammals

text: rather than laying eggs, and who feed their young with milk.
By laughing, young mammals, sometimes called juveniles,
signal that they want to play.
And young rats who don't laugh back are more likely to get a bite than a giggle,
and a rat bite is nothing to laugh about.
What a lot of facts we've learnt about laughter, Neil.
Yes, we could almost be experts on laughter.
speaker: Sam

text: Gapologists, isn't that what you called them, sir?
Ah yes,
speaker: Sam

text: In my quiz question, I asked you to name the scientific study of laughter
and its effects on the body.
I'm almost certain it's not gigglogy or gapology,
so the answer must be...
Gelatology!
The correct answer! Well done, Neil
speaker: Sam

text: I knew you were good for a laugh.
Okay, let's recap the vocabulary from the programme
before you think up any more terrible jokes.
First, we had ribcage, the structure in your chest,
which is made of ribs, and produces the sound of laughter.
The adjective primitive relates to the simple, natural way humans lived
speaker: primitive

text: in the early stages of development.
There are different types of laughter, including giggles,
childlike laughter, in a quiet but uncontrolled way.
And gaffors, when you laugh out loud, often at something someone has said.
Mammals are animals, including humans,
speaker: guffaw

text: which give birth to live young and feed them with milk.
And finally, a young animal, which is not fully grown, can be called a juvenile.
speaker: juvenile.

text: Well, it's been a laugh a minute, Sam, but unfortunately, our six minutes are up.
Join us again soon for more trending topics,
speaker: Sam

text: useful vocabulary, and who knows, maybe some terrible jokes,
here at six minutes English. Bye for now.
Goodbye.
